entry.title: What can I do to feel like I belong in the Tech community?
entry.content:
When I was a teenager, in the 00â€™s, the internet gave me net-positive energy and optimism. It was still very novel, and there was a lot of opportunity to discover niche communities that overlapped with my interests. I felt like part of an in-crowd and it deeply influenced my life.

I have continuously been connected online (Metaphorically. Bc I grew up with dial-up). Much of the novelty has long worn off.

Itâ€™s been an exhausting yearðŸ”—

I was laid off early in the year due to the pandemic. Due to the sudden loss of human interaction, I have been revisiting some of that yearning for connection as I transition to starting a business from scratch (more about that some other time). As a necessity, I am dependent on the internet for the majority of my human interaction. Maybe this is me being mentally old, but I feel the current energy of my echochamber to be more net-negative and Iâ€™m hoping I can introduce myself to people who build others up.

Niche communities are difficult for me to discover with the same ease as when I was young. Thatâ€™s not a reason enough for me to stop looking! So thatâ€™s fine. Iâ€™ll start looking where Iâ€™m at. For professional reasons, I need to start in Tech. So Iâ€™ll need to be more specific, because Tech is HUGE.

Searching for my k-nearest neighborsðŸ”—

Iâ€™ll spare you the rest of the thought exercise. Iâ€™ve been focusing my efforts within the Rust community. Why? Itâ€™s reignited my joy in writing code again, and Iâ€™m trying to start my business with it. And because people love it!

With a few years under my belt, Iâ€™ve finally reached a point in my Rust development that I no longer consider myself a beginner and I can be productive. Great! Well, now what?

What have I been doing?ðŸ”—

  • Regularly posting blog posts with a purpose of educating or sharing an experience as a non-expert
  • Hanging out around Tech Twitter and occasionally commenting and retweeting
  • Streaming writing Rust code for a few hours at least once a week
  • Joining so many Slack/Discord/Matrix/Gitter/IRC communities. Mostly lurking, but participating occasionally
  • Maintaining a Rust crate and occasionally asking related projects if they would like to depend on it

What have I been expecting?ðŸ”—

Part of me was hoping eventually after seeing the same same faces, same namesâ€¦ that I would feel like I had joined the community and Iâ€™d stop feeling so intimidated. Perhaps that I would have experienced some subtle mutual acknowledgement of acquaintance? (I have since been lowering my expectations, fwiw. I now believe it is my responsibility to initiate the interactions with potential personal meaning or expectation.)

What have I not been doing?ðŸ”—

  • Actively inviting conversation
  • Stepping out of my comfort zone to ask for feedback

Wonâ€™t you be my neighbor?ðŸ”—

When was the last time you joined a new community? What was the defining moment when you felt like you belonged?

I donâ€™t feel unwelcome in Tech, but I feel invisible. My attempts to extend my reach out to those who might actually care to connect has random-like results. Not for lack of trying. But admittedly, I am placing too much value in establishing consistency before figuring out what works for me.

I don't know what options to try next. Iâ€™m not fishing for pity, but I am looking for advice. How do I find my audience? How can my audience find me?

Join the discussion on my post at Dev.to or on Twitter
